Of the Italians who said they supported the neo-Fascist Italian Gooial Move¬

DUMA made one more division >n this first question — a division between
Italian men and women. Bo far as Italian men were concerned, their collective
preference was a tossup between Americans and French, only ten per cent put us
in fourth place and another ten per cent designated the French as least popular.
But the women gave Americans a slight edge, only five oer cent of them put us in
last place, while seven per oent designated the French.
Italian men and women also differed in their attitudes toward tho Germans.
Only 16 per cent of the men said they had the least sympathy for the Germans,
while 33 per cent of the women liked the Germans least among the four nationali¬
ties*
But perhaps I have given too much attention to this matter of sympathy for
different nationalities. It is hardly a constructive thing, even if interesting.
For its second major question, DOXA asked Italians to select three adjectives
from a list of 24 that would best describe Americans. And the adjective chosen
most often was the word, “generous.* Thirty eight per cent of Italians polled
used “generous* a® one of their three adjective® by which to describe Americans.
In second place, with 37 per cent, was the word, “practical. ”
